Graphical abstract The oxygen-vacancy-rich GDS NTs as solid-state composite electrolyte fillers are successfully prepared for the first time. And the excellent electrochemical properties of the assembled batteries with the composite electrolyte can be obtained. All-solid-state electrolytes are exceedingly attractive because of the outstanding inherent safety and energy density compared to liquid electrolytes. Whereas, it is still formidable to simultaneously design solid electrolytes with favorable electrode/electrolyte interface compatibility and high ionic conductivity in a simple and scalable manner. Hence, the oxygen-vacancy-rich Gd-doped SnO2 nanotubes (GDS NTs) are innovatively prepared and applied to the electrolyte of all-solid-state lithium metal batteries for the first time. The addition of GDS NTs can validly construct long-range continuous ion transport networks in the poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO)-based system and greatly improve the mechanical properties of the electrolyte. Compared to the PEO-based electrolyte, the composite electrolyte displays a higher lithium ion conductivity of 2.41 × 10–4 S cm−1 at 30 ℃, a higher lithium ion transference number up to 0.62 and a wider electrochemical window of 5 V at 50 ℃. In addition, the composite electrolyte manifests outstanding compatibility with high-voltage LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) cathode, LiFePO4 cathode and lithium metal anode. The assembled Li/Li symmetric battery exhibits stable Li plating/stripping cycling performance, which can cycle steadily for 1500 h at a capacity of 0.3 mA h cm−2. And Li/LiFePO4 battery still maintains a high capacity of 131.54 mA h g−1 at 0.5C after 800 cycles, which has a superior capacity retention rate of 93.2%. The obtained novel composite electrolyte has promising application prospects in the field of all-solid-state lithium metal cells. Keywords All-solid-state lithium metal batteries Gd-doped SnO2 nanotubes Interfacial stability Oxygen vacancies Solid-state composite electrolytes 1 Introduction With the scarcity of natural resources and the continuous improvement of people's living standards, individuals have a greater demand for electric components. Nowadays, almost all practical applications of lithium batteries are equipped with liquid electrolytes. And liquid lithium batteries are widely applied in the electrification of transportation, especially in electronic goods and electric vehicles, et al. [1]. Nevertheless, liquid lithium batteries have limited energy density and poor thermal stability [2,3]. Owing to the flammability of liquid electrolytes, there are a variety of safety hazards during storage and application [4–6]. Therefore, a large number of researchers have made many attempts to deal with this situation [7]. The use of all-solid-state electrolytes instead of organic liquid electrolytes can not only fundamentally deal with the safety problems caused by liquid leakage, but also can effectively inhibit the occurrence of side reactions. Based on these merits, the safety performance and electrochemical performance of the battery can be significantly enhanced [8–11]. Solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) are one of the key components of all-solid-state lithium metal battery, which can be generally divided into two categories: Inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs) and Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) [12]. ISEs generally exhibit excellent Li+ ions mobility and conductivity, which are extremely beneficial for enhancing the integral property of all-solid-state batteries [13]. Nonetheless, ISEs are invariably prepared by repeated solid-phase sintering and powder compression, so the preparation cost and time for some ISEs required more compared with other methods. Besides, ISEs also have some shortcomings such as high brittleness and poor electrolyte/electrode interface stability and so on [14]. The unstable solid electrolyte interface easily leads to the uncontrolled growth of lithium dendrites, which greatly limits the fast development of all-solid lithium metal batteries [15,16]. The SPEs based on polymer matrix and lithium salts can be prepared by the doctor-blade or tape-casting method, which has great potential for industrial-scale production. Moreover, SPEs have favorable film-forming properties including high flexibility and good compatibility with electrode interfaces [17–20]. But at the same time, SPEs also retain some disadvantages. The most representative of polymer-based electrolytes is PEO. Firstly, the transport of lithium ions invariably takes place in the amorphous region through coordination and dissociation with oxygen atoms in the PEO matrix. Nevertheless, the crystallinity of PEO is relatively high, which is very unfavorable for the transfer of Li+ ions. Secondly, the co-existence of crystalline and amorphous phases in PEO polymers leads to the heterogeneous migration of Li+ ions, which eventually results in the growth of Li dendrites. Moreover, PEO-based electrolytes have dreadful mechanical strength. When the Li dendrites grow to a certain extent, the lithium dendrites may pierce the PEO-based electrolyte, resulting in the failure of the cycled cell [21–25]. In order to enhance the performance of the electrolytes, a multitude of researchers have focused on adding functional inorganic nanofillers to the polymer matrices [26–28]. The composite solid electrolytes prepared by adding fillers with high Li+ conductivity to the SPEs have a wide electrochemical stability window, excellent ionic conductivity, good flexibility and facile synthesis [29]. In particular, the composite electrolyte has good compatibility with the electrode, and it has received extensive attention [30,31]. The concept of introducing nanomaterials into SSEs was proposed in 1982. Weston et al. enhanced the performance of electrolyte by adding inert fillers to polymer electrolytes [32]. After continuous exploration, a variety of researchers found that adding one-dimensional (1D) inorganic nanofillers (nanofibers, nanowires, nanorods, nanotubes, etc.) to the SPEs also can significantly enhance the Li+ ion conductivity. In contrast to nanoparticles, 1D nanofillers can provide long-range continuous ion transport channels [33,34]. Simultaneously, the mechanical properties and electrochemical stability are significantly improved. As a result, a multitude of 1D nanomaterials have been applied to the SPEs, such as the extensively researched active ceramic garnet-type (Li7La3Zr2O12 [35], Li6.25La3Zr2Al0.25O12 [36]) and perovskite-type (Li0.33La0.557TiO3 [37], aluminum-doped Li0.33La0.557TiO3 [38]) nanofibers, inert ceramic nanofillers like CeO2 nanowires [29], TiO2 nanowires [39] SiO2 nanofibers [40], Y2O3-doped ZrO2 (YSZ) nanowires [41] and halloysite nanoclay (HNT) [42] and so on. Meanwhile, Sheng et al. added Mg2B2O5 nanowires to the PEO-based electrolytes, which provided long-range continuous channels for Li+ ions transport and simultaneously enhanced Li+ ions conductivity. Owing to the excellent flame retardant properties and mechanical strength of the Mg2B2O5 nanowire additives, the flame retardant properties and mechanical properties of the composite solid electrolytes can be also improved [43]. In summary, adding one-dimensional ceramic nanofillers to SPEs can effectively enhance the ionic conductivity of Li+ ions, and validly improve the electrochemical and mechanical properties of batteries. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that the addition of oxygen-vacancy-rich nanofillers can effectively enhance the ionic conductivity of composite solid electrolytes [31,41]. For instance, Chen et al. doped oxygen-vacancy-rich Sm-doped CeO2 one-dimensional nanowires in the PVDF-based system [44]. The Sm-doped CeO2 nanowires provided long-range continuous transport channels for Li+ ions, which was extremely beneficial to the enhancement of ionic conductivity. Meanwhile, the oxygen vacancies in the nanowires were positively charged and can be acted as Lewis acid sites in the composite solid electrolyte, which can strongly interact with anions of lithium salts to release lithium ions for enhancing the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. Furthermore, the inner surface of 1D tubular materials is also promising to be filled with various polymers providing a fast diffusion interface for Li+ ions. For example, Zhang et al. added Ca-doped CeO2 nanotubes to the PEO-based system to prepare composite solid electrolytes [45]. The hollow structure in the Ca-CeO2 nanotubes can provide more organic–inorganic contact interfaces, which can validly inhibit the recrystallization of the electrolyte, resulting in improved Li+ ions conductivity of the composite electrolyte. In particular, for common inorganic nanofibers/nanowairs fillers, lithium ions can only be transported speedily along the outer surface of the nanofillers. Whereas, both the inner and outer surfaces of the nanotubes can be acted as the fast transport channels for free Li+ ions dissociated from lithium salts, which extremely improves the transport of lithium ions in the PEO-based matrix between electrodes and electrolytes. What interests us is that the oxygen-vacancy-rich SnO2 material has been applied to a variety of applications including sensors [46], catalysis [47], lithium battery anodes [48] due to the oxygen vacancies on its surface which can provide more active sites. Moreover, it is worth noting that elemental Gd doping can further enhance the concentration of oxygen vacancies [49]. However, up to now, it has not been reported that SnO2-based nanomaterials are applied to the composite solid electrolytes as fillers. Hence, combining the above advantages, we consider whether the oxygen-vacancy-rich SnO2-based nanotubes can be designed and applied to all-solid-state lithium metal batteries. In this work, combining the merits of surface functionalization and hollow structure, the oxygen-vacancy-rich GDS NTs are prepared via the electro-blow spinning and high-temperature calcination methods and applied to all-solid-state lithium metal batteries for the first time, which can validly enhance the electrochemical and mechanical properties of the electrolyte. Firstly, the hollow structure in the prepared GDS NTs can provide the largest contact area with the PEO/LiTFSI system among these prepared samples. And both the inner and outer surfaces of the GDS NTs can be acted as the long-range continuous transport channels for lithium ions, which extremely improve lithium ion transmission. Secondly, the inorganic oxide GDS NTs with plenty of oxygen vacancies can strongly interact with anions in lithium salts to boost the dissociation of lithium salts to release lithium ions, resulting in improved ionic conductivity of electrolytes. Furthermore, SnO2 has a good affinity for lithium, which can credibly inhibit the formation of lithium dendrites. Last but not least, the addition of one-dimensional GDS NTs also can validly reduce the crystallinity of PEO, thereby promoting the transport of Li+ ions. Based on the above advantages, the ionic conductivity of the prepared composite electrolyte is as high as 2.41 × 10–4 S cm−1 at 30 ℃. Simultaneously, the assembled Li/LiFePO4 cell still maintains a high capacity of 131.54 mA h g−1 at 0.5C after 800 cycles, which has a promising capacity retention rate of 93.2%. 2 Experimental The preparation processes of Gd-doped SnO2 nanotubes and composite solid electrolytes, structure characterization, assembly of all-solid-state batteries and electrochemical characterization are completely presented and obviously illustrated in the Supplementary Materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of GDS NTs Fig. 1 (a) briefly illustrates the preparation process of the GDS NTs. As manifested in the figure, the GDS NTs are prepared via the electro-blow spinning and high-temperature calcination processes. Compared with the ceramic nanorods and nanowires prepared by traditional hydrothermal synthesis, the nanofibers prepared via the electro-blown spinning method have a higher aspect ratio [25], so more long-range continuous Li+ ions transport channels can be provided. Moreover, it is worth noting that the viscosity of the solution is extremely significant for the morphology of the fibers during the electro-blown spinning process [50]. The solvent molecules containing Gd(NO3)3·6H2O and SnCl4·5H2O were uniformly dispersed in the outer layer of PVP clusters under suitable viscosity conditions. After the precursor GDS NTs (Fig. S1a) are dried at a certain temperature, the electrostatic force gradually weakens, so that the polymers with ceramic filler in the outer layer are also rather stable. During the high-temperature calcination process, the inner layer of PVP shrinks thermally as the temperature slowly increases, and immediately moves to the outer layer. Simultaneously, the outer structure remains almost unchanged. With the increase of temperature, the nanofibers form hollow structures. Correspondingly, the PVP is progressively decomposed, and the remaining ceramic materials are Gd-SnO2 products. The final GDS NTs can be obtained when the PVP is entirely decomposed [45,51]. In order to obtain GDS NTs with superior hollow morphology, the preparation process is explored in three aspects: calcination temperature, heating rate and Gd(NO3)3·6H2O content. Fig. S1(b–h) present the corresponding SEM images of the GDS NTs after calcination under the conditions of different calcination temperature (600, 800 and 1000 ℃), heating rate (2, 5 and 10 ℃ min−1) and Gd(NO3)3·6H2O content (1, 1.2 and 1.4 g). Intriguingly, it is obvious that the hollow GDS NTs with superior morphology can be obtained at the calcination temperature of 800 ℃, in which the additional amount of Gd(NO3)3·6H2O is 1.2 g and the heating rate is 5 ℃ min−1. Moreover, it can be found that pure SnO2 nanotubes (SnO2 NTs) can be prepared by the same method (Fig. S1i). Fig. 1(b) indicates the cross-sectional view of the composite electrolyte. The added GDS NTs fillers are evenly dispersed in the composite electrolyte, which forms a three-dimensional transport framework for Li+ ions and improves the mechanical strength of the PEO-based electrolyte. As manifested in Fig. 1(c and d), for common inorganic nanofibers fillers, lithium ions can only be transported speedily along the outer surface of the nanofibers. Whereas, the hollow structures of the prepared GDS NTs provide more organic–inorganic interfaces between PEO and GDS NTs for the surface and interior of GDS NTs. And it is obvious that both the surface and interior of the GDS NTs can be acted as the fast transport channels for free Li+ dissociated from lithium salts, which extremely improves the transport of lithium ions in the PEO-based composite electrolyte between electrodes and electrolytes. Moreover, the addition of the prepared GDS NTs also can validly reduce the crystallinity of PEO, thereby promoting the transport of Li+ ions. In addition, the oxygen-vacancy-rich GDS NTs can strongly interact with LiTFSI– ions to boost the dissociation of lithium salts, resulting in enhanced Li+ ions conductivity of electrolytes for a solid state lithium cell. 3.2 Characterization of GDS NTs The prepared GDS NTs with hollow structure exhibited three obvious peaks at 26.6°, 33.9° and 51.8° as illustrated in Fig. 2 (a), corresponding to the (110), (101) and (211) planes. This result is compatible with the pure SnO2 (JCPDS 41–1445), and there are some other diffraction peaks appearing, proving the successful doping of Gd element [52]. From Fig. S2, it can be seen that the lattice spacing gradually becomes large with the increase of Gd content in the (110) plane, and the highest peak gradually migrates to the left. The result is mainly because that the atomic radius of Gd is larger than that of Sn. Therefore, the doping with a larger radius of Gd element results in a larger lattice spacing and a correspondingly smaller diffraction peak in SnO2. Consequently, it can be found that the Gd doping is successful in the SnO2 nanotubes. All in all, these tested results indicate that the addition of Gd can increase the lattice spacing, which facilitates fast transport of Li+. Fig. 2(b) clearly shows the morphology of the prepared GDS NTs with hollow structure. It is evident that the prepared nanotubes can maintain one-dimensional elongated hollow tube morphology with a relatively uniform of 400–500 nm. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distribution curves of the prepared GDS NTs are manifested in Fig. 2(c), which further demonstrate the formation of hollow structures. Meanwhile, when compared to the SnO2 NTs (12.65 m−2 g−1) as illustrated in Fig. S3, the prepared GDS NTs exhibited a larger specific surface area (19.27 m−2 g−1), which makes the interfacial contact between the ceramic nanotube and polymer more sufficient. As a result, the recrystallization of PEO can be effectively suppressed. In particular, the HR-TEM test is used to clearly observe the nanostructure of the prepared GDS NTs. As presented in Fig. 2(d), by comparing with the lattice fringes in HR-TEM image, it can be calibrated that the interplanar spacing is 0.237 nm, which corresponds to the (200) plane of SnO2. As manifested in Fig. 2(e), the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern indicates the excellent crystallinity within the prepared GDS NTs, which illustrates D-spacing values of GDS NTs with (110) (101), (200) and (211) planes [53]. As illustrated in Fig. 2(f–i), the element mappings can be used to prove the uniform distribution of elements Sn and Gd, which also confirms the successful doping of Gd element. These results demonstrate the viability of the strategy and the favorable hollow structure of the GDS NTs, which will provide a guarantee for obtaining composite solid electrolytes with excellent electrochemical performance. 3.3 Characterization of GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte The XRD patterns of the prepared GDS NTs, 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFFSI composite electrolyte and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFFSI composite electrolyte are manifested in Fig. 3 (a). Obviously, the pure PEO-based system has two obvious peaks at 18.8° and 23.1° that are consistent with the crystalline phase of PEO matrix. These peaks in 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFFSI composite electrolyte become weaker after the introduction of GDS NTs, indicating that the prepared GDS NTs have the effect of reducing the crystallinity of PEO matrix, which is beneficial to the Li+ ions transmission in PEO-based system. The XRD patterns of the composite electrolytes obviously illustrate that the diffraction peaks of the GDS NTs appear in the prepared electrolyte with GDS NTs, which indicates the promising stability of GDS NTs in the PEO-based composite electrolyte can be realized. Fig. 3(b) shows that the thickness of the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFFSI electrolyte for the long cycle test is about 110 μm. Meanwhile, as manifested in Fig. 3(c), the image of the prepared composite electrolyte surface illustrates that the GDS NTs are uniformly dispersed in the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFFSI electrolyte, which further proves that the GDS NTs are interwoven in the polymer matrix to form a network and provide long-range continuous channels for Li+ ions transport. Fig. 3(d) indicates the DSC curves of the SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI and X GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI (X is 0, 5, 10 and 15) electrolytes. The lowest glass transition temperature (T g) of the composite electrolytes with inorganic fillers is lower when compared to 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte (–41.2 ℃). Especially the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI (–48.9 ℃), which strongly confirms that the introduction of GDS NTs can validly facilitate the campaign of molecular chains and decrease the crystallization of polymer [37]. Since all-solid-state batteries usually operate in different temperature ranges, thermal stability also is particularly indispensable for solid-state electrolytes. Fig. 3(e) clearly manifests the TG curves of the composite electrolytes from 50 to 800 ℃. And the weight loss is attributed to moisture absorption from the atmosphere below 200 ℃. Nonetheless, in the range of 200 to 640 ℃, the weight reduction is mainly because of the decomposition of LiTFSI and PEO. The thermal stability of GDS NTs and SnO2 NTs lead to the difference in final residual mass. The result is because that the final products can only come from the GDS NTs and LiTFSI decomposition. It is obvious that the addition of GDS NTs can significantly improve the thermal stability of composite electrolytes. As manifested in Fig. 3(f), the ionic conductivities of three different composite electrolytes are demonstrated obviously. Among all composite electrolytes, the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte has the highest Li+ conductivity. It is understandable that the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte has more long-range continuous lithium ion transport channels and more organic–inorganic interfaces due to the addition of GDS NTs, thereby effectively enhancing the ionic conductivity of the composite electrolyte. It is worth mentioning that the ionic conductivity of the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte at 30 ℃ is further improved to 2.41 × 10–4 S cm−1, which is much higher than PEO-based electrolyte without inorganic fillers. Conversely, excessive filling of GDS NTs in PEO polymer causes the agglomeration of GDS NTs, which leads to the decrease of ionic conductivity [54]. Accordingly, it can be concluded that the introduction of GDS NTs can greatly enhance the Li+ ions transport capability of the PEO-based electrolyte. The ability of lithium ion migration can be assessed by the lithium ion transference number. Fig. 3(g and h) illustrates the chronoamperometry curves of Li/Li symmetrical batteries at 50 ℃. And it can be calculated that the Li+ migration number of the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte is 0.62 (Fig. 3g) through the test data, which is evidently higher than 0.16 of 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte (Fig. 3h) and 0.37 of SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte (Fig. S4). The addition of GDS NTs can improve the σ and t Li + values of PEO-based electrolyte, mainly owing to two reasons: Firstly, the transport of lithium ions is facilitated by the long-range continuously fast Li+ ion transport channels and more organic/inorganic interfaces due to the addition of GDS NTs. Secondly, the GDS NTs with hollow structure break the regular arrangement of the PEO polymer and validly accelerate the of Li+ ion transport during the rearrangement of PEO. The electrochemical stability also is a significant criterion of electrolyte. Meanwhile, the LSV curves of the 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI, SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolytes are tested to evaluate the electrochemical stability of the electrolytes as illustrated in Fig. 3(i). It is worth mentioning that the breakdown voltages of SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolytes reached 4.9 and 5.0 V after the addition of the prepared SnO2 NTs and GDS NTs, which is obviously higher than that without ceramic nanofillers (4.3 V). These results well demonstrate that the addition of the prepared GDS NTs is rather beneficial to enhance the electrochemical stability of the electrolyte, meaning that it can be well matched with high-voltage cathode materials. 3.4 Interaction between GDS NTs and PEO/LiTFSI matrix Based on previous studies on inorganic ceramic materials in polymer electrolytes, the main working mechanism of GDS NTs in PEO-based electrolytes can be illustrated from two aspects: On the one hand, PEO with low crystallinity is well known to facilitate the migration of Li+ ions. It is obvious that the DSC and XRD patterns have well confirmed that the introduction of GDS NTs can validly hinder the recombination of PEO chains and reduce the crystallinity of PEO polymer. On the other hand, oxygen vacancies are well-known regions of positive potential. Based on Lewis acid-base interactions, the oxygen-vacancy-rich GDS NTs can facilitate the dissociation of LiTFSI to generate more Li+ ions. Furthermore, it is worth noting that owing to the wide specific surface area and hollow structure of GDS NTs, the introduction of the prepared GDS NTs can not only possess more organic–inorganic interfaces, but also provide long-range continuous Li+ ion transport channels in the PEO-based electrolytes. As illustrated in Fig. S5, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurement obtained an obvious characteristic EPR signal, which provided fingerprint evidence for probing oxygen vacancies. The XPS analysis is a viable method to investigate the chemical composition and valence state of GDS NTs as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The distinct Gd, Sn, and O signals are exhibited in the prepared GDS NTs, which confirms the successful preparation of GDS NTs again. Fig. 4(b) indicates the binding energy of Gd at 148.4 eV and 143.0 eV of 4d 3/2 and 4d 5/2 on the surface of GDS NTs [55]. The splitting of orbitals can be attributed to the + 3 oxidation state of the Gd element. Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 4(c), the Sn species exist in the valence form of + 4, which can be confirmed by the two peaks of Sn 3d 3/2 (495.2 eV) and Sn 3d 5/2 (486.7 eV) in the prepared GDS NTs [56]. More importantly, the influence of the prepared GDS NTs on PEO/LiTFSI matrix was further investigated to clarify the chemical interactions among ceramic GDS NTs, Li+ ions and PEO matrix. Fig. 4(d) illustrates the FTIR spectra for PEO, LiTFSI, GDS NTs, 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI, and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI in the range of 4000–400 cm−1. Since it is not liable to capture small differences from Fig. 4(d), the detailed spectrum in the 1400–1150 cm−1 range is shown in Fig. 4(e). Meanwhile, the main peaks around 1351, 1340, 1281 and 1241 cm−1 in both 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolytes are consistent with PEO by comparing the FTIR spectra of GDS NTs, LiTFSI and PEO. And other distinct peaks correspond to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching of -CF3 and -SO2 groups in LiTFSI. The addition of GDS NTs prompts the shift of the peaks belonging to the stretching of -SO2- from 1332.04 and 1302.99 cm−1 to 1331.05 and 1301.16 cm−1. Correspondingly, the peaks for symmetric stretching of -CF3 shift from 1251.06 and 1228.52 cm−1 to 1253.59 and 1227.40 cm−1. Simultaneously, it also can be observed that the subtle movement of peaks, which are consistent with the asymmetric stretching of -CF3. These shifts in -SO2 and -CF3 groups are attributed to the intense interaction between TFSI– anions and GDS NTs, and greatly enhance the dissociation of LiTFSI to generate more Li+ ions [45]. In addition, the peak at around 740 cm−1 is consistent with the SN stretching of TFSI– as manifested in Fig. 4(f). Compared to the 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte, the peak intensity at 740 cm−1 corresponding to the free imide bands of SN stretching can be increased obviously. Based on the previous EPR measurement, it also has been confirmed that the prepared GDS NTs have abundant oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies on the inner and outer surfaces of GDS NTs can strongly interact with TFSI– anions, which effectively promotes the dissociation of lithium salts. In addition, the addition of prepared GDS NTs also can reduce the crystallinity of PEO. And the inner and outer surfaces of GDS NTs can be used as fast transport channels for lithium ions, thereby effectively accelerating the transport of lithium ions. 3.5 Electrochemical performances of Li/Li cells with composite electrolyte In order to ensure the cycling stability of the assembled all-solid-state lithium batteries, it is particularly important to enhance the compatibility and stability of metal electrode/electrolyte interface. The introduction of the prepared GDS NTs fillers can validly improve the overall mechanical strength of PEO-based electrolytes and prevent the infiltration of Li dendrites from causing short circuit. The reason is that adding GDS NTs to the PEO matrix can build a cross-linking network owing to the large specific surface area and hollow structure of GDS NTs. The interconnected network between the GDS NTs themselves and the extensive organic/inorganic interfaces between GDS NTs and PEO chains particularly enhance the mechanical strength of PEO-based electrolyte membranes. Meanwhile, the obtained electrolyte membranes with improved mechanical properties can tremendously suppress the growth of Li dendrites, which significantly enhances the cycling stability of the assembled solid-state lithium batteries. The maximum endurable current density of the cycled all-solid-state lithium metal cell without failure is generally defined as the critical current density (CCD). Consequently, the CCD is a crucial parameter to help determine the rate-determining steps of lithium kinetics in the all-solid-state lithium metal batteries [57]. To investigate the effect of ceramic fillers on the critical current density of PEO-based systems, the voltage–time curves of Li/Li batteries with 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFS| and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/ LiTFSI composite electrolytes monitored at progressively increasing current densities are measured as shown in Fig. 5 (a). Notably, the Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric cells indicate a higher CCD (0.5 mA cm−2) when compared to the cells using the 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte (0.35 mA cm−2). It can be found that Li dendrites of Li|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li batteries are easily form at 0.4 mA cm−2, which demonstrates the poor electrode/electrolyte interface stability during cycling. In addition, the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte has smaller charge transfer resistance and larger tLi + than the pure PEO-based system. And the assembled Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell is less prone to serious concentration polarization because of the fast transmission of Li+ ions at the electrode/electrolyte interface. Thus, the CCD value can be significantly enhanced for the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte, which means that the PEO-based electrolyte with the addition of GDS NTs can validly suppress the formation of Li dendrites. In order to research the Li dendrite suppression ability of doped ceramic nanotube fillers, the Li plating/stripping behavior in galvanostatic tests is subsequently investigated. Especially, the voltage–time profile of Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric battery is illustrated in Fig. 5(b). It is worth mentioning that the assembled Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell can cycle steadily at a current of 0.8 mA cm−2 without short-circuiting. Whereas, the Li/Li symmetric battery using 0 GDS NTs/ PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte becomes unsteady when the current is 0.2 mA cm−2 (Fig. S6) and Li/Li symmetric cell with SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI has a larger polarization voltage (Fig. S7). This phenomenon indicates that Li dendrites are simply formed in 0 GDS NTs/PEO/ LiTFSI electrolyte even at lower plating capacities. Fortunately, the Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric battery can withstand higher current densities, which can credibly inhibit the formation of Li dendrites during cycling. In addition, the performance of the assembled solid-state lithium metal batteries are further evaluated at a higher capacity. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the assembled cells with 10 GDS NTs/ PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte exhibit excellent cycling performance at the area capacity of 0.2 mA h cm−2. Even when the area capacity is set to 0.4 mA h cm−2, the Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cells can still be stable under the current density of 0.4 mA cm−2 (Fig. S8). Fig. 5(d and e) illustrates the long-cycle tests of Li/Li symmetric cells using 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte under two kinds of capacities (0.2 and 0.3 mA h cm−2). The Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric cell can be cycled stably for 1500 h at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 when the capacity is further adjusted to 0.2 mA h cm−2 (Fig. 5d). Conversely, at a capacity of 0.1 mA h cm−2 for plating/delithiation per cycle, the Li|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric battery remains stable for only 180 h even at 0.1 mA cm−2 with a large polarization voltage, and the polarization voltage also increases significantly with the number of cycles (Fig. S9). In addition, when the metal lithium plating/stripping capacity per cycle is adjusted to 0.3 mA h cm−2, the cell voltage value can still remain steady even if the current density is changed from 0.2 to 0.3 mA cm−2. There is growing evidence that the Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li battery can be cycled stably for a long time up to 1500 h when the current is restored to 0.2 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5e). All in all, the Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric battery exhibits excellent cycling stability when compared to the Li|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric cell, which illustrates that the obtained 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte can validly suppress the formation of Li dendrites. Specifically, due to the lacking mechanical properties and poor ionic conductivity of pure PEO electrolytes, Li dendrites can simply form to penetrate the polymer matrix. But the inhibition of lithium dendrites by the prepared GDS NTs is mainly attributed to two aspects: Firstly, the mechanical properties of the composite electrolyte are validly enhanced owing to the introduction of prepared GDS NTs. Secondly, the prepared oxygen-vacancy-rich GDS NTs can interact with TFSI– anions, leading to a worse binding force of Li+ and TFSI–, which significantly promotes the dissociation of LiTFSI to generate more Li+. Moreover, the prepared GDS NTs effectively reduce the crystallinity of PEO and provide long-range continuously fast lithium ion transport channels. These merits can facilitate the high-speed Li+ ion migration and enhance ionic conductivity, thus validly inhibiting the formation of Li dendrites. The changes at the cross-sectional interfaces of Li/Li symmetric batteries during the lithium deposition process can be tracked and observed by an in situ device through the optical microscope. At 50 ℃, the Li/Li symmetric cells are tested at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2. Particularly, the changes of electrode/electrolyte can be captured in real time through a quartz glass viewing window. Meanwhile, tiny Li dendrites can be found at the deposition side interface of the Li|0 GDS NTs/ PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell in less than 30 min as illustrated in Fig. 5(f). And Li dendrite growth is extremely obvious after 60 min, which can be clearly seen in the rightmost partial magnified image. Moreover, the growth of lithium dendrites can destabilize the electrode/electrolyte interface, resulting in the short-circuiting of the cell. In contrast, as manifested in Fig. 5(g), the assembled Li|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li symmetric battery maintains superior stability of the electrolyte/electrode interface for 2 h. It is obvious that the composite electrolyte with the introduction of GDS NTs filler has superior performance in inhibiting the formation of lithium dendrites, which is because the interconnected ion transport network constructed by the prepared GDS NTs can validly boost the uniform deposition of Li+ ions during the charge/discharge processes. 3.6 Cycling performances of LiFePO4/Li and NMC/Li cells with composite electrolyte Since the stability between metal lithium and the prepared 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte has been demonstrated, LiFePO4|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cells are used to assess electrode/electrolyte interface stability. As illustrated in Fig. 6 (a), the rate performances of the LiFePO4|10 GDS NTs/PEO /LiTFSI|Li and LiFePO4|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cells from 0.1C to 1C are achieved under 50 ℃. It is worth mentioning that the discharge capacity of the assembled LiFePO4|10 GDS NTs/PEO /LiTFSI|Li cell delivers higher capacity than those batteries with 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI and SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolytes, which indicates that the addition of the prepared GDS NTs can significantly increase rate capability. Specifically, the LiFePO4|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell displays high initial capacities of about 161.27, 160.97, 159.19, and 153.10 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, and 1C. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the presented smooth charge–discharge curves illustrate the excellent surface stability of the 10 GDS NTs/ PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte and electrode. Furthermore, the electrochemical impedance plots of LiFePO4/Li batteries with different electrolytes are illustrated in Fig. 6(c). It is obvious that the impedance of the LiFePO4/Li battery with 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte (155.0 Ω) is smaller than that with SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI (234.4 Ω) and 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI (346.1 Ω), which well demonstrates the role of the prepared GDS NTs filler. Subsequently, the long-term cycling of the assembled cells with the LiFePO4 cathode is investigated. As manifested in Fig. 6(d), it is worth mentioning that the discharge capacity of LiFePO4/Li cell with 10 GDS NTs/PEO/ LiTFSI electrolyte still remains 131.54 mA h g−1 after 800 cycles at 0.5C, which is corresponding to a superior capacity retention of about 93.2%. And under the condition of higher loading of active material, the battery still maintains over 99% Coulombic efficiency after 70 cycles (Fig. S10). On the contrary, the LiFePO4|0 GDS NTs/PEO/ LiTFSI|Li cell exhibits poor cycling stability with capacity retention of 44.9% after 487 cycles at 0.5C. Moreover, Fig. 6(e) further demonstrates that the battery with 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte expresses comparatively smooth charge/discharge curves of several different cycles, which indicates the cycling stability of the assembled cell. As illustrated in Fig. 6(f and g), the assembled LiFePO4|10 GDS NTs/PEO/ LiTFSI|Li battery still demonstrates excellent electrochemical stability at 1C. Meanwhile, it is worth noting that the large capacity retention of the cell still remains at 70.4% after 800 cycles and the Coulombic efficiency is consistently retained at about 99.7%. Whereas, the discharge capacity of LiFePO4|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell is only 80.8 mA h g−1 after 243 cycles (Fig. S11). Compared with the LiFePO4|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell, the LiFePO4|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li battery exhibits excellent electrochemical performance, which can be attributed to the construction of long-range continuous lithium ion transport channels and the favorable interface compatibility. At low temperature, the interfacial impedance increases and reaction kinetics reduces due to the poor compatibility between electrolyte and cell electrodes. Therefore, the assembled LiFePO4|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li battery exhibits a reduced initial discharge specific capacity as shown in Fig. S12. Nevertheless, the battery can cycle steadily for more than 40 cycles, which fully demonstrates the excellent electrochemical performance of the composite electrolyte. Furthermore, all-solid-state NMC/Li cells with different electrolytes are also assembled to assess the high voltage cathode/electrolyte interface stability. The impedance curves of the NMC/Li cells coupled with 0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI, SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolytes before cycling are carried out to plenty demonstrate the advantages of the 10 GDS NTs/ PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte. As a result, the initial impedance of the NMC|10 GDS NTs/ PEO/LiTFSI|Li battery is only 149.2 Ω, while the impedance of the NMC|SnO2 NTs/ PEO/LiTFSI|Li and NMC|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li batteries increase to 313.4 Ω and 505.8 Ω (Fig. 7 a). And the smaller initial impedance of the battery equipped with 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte can be attributed to the superior interface compatibility between high-voltage electrode and composite electrolyte. Moreover, Fig. 7(b) also presents the rate capability of NMC/Li cells at various rates. In particular, the discharge capacities of the NMC|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell at current densities of 0.1, 0.3 and 0.5C are 182.2, 159.4 and 135.3 mA h g−1, which are obviously higher than the NMC|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li and NMC|SnO2 NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cells. As manifested in Fig. 7(c), the typical discharge–charge curves of NMC|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell at different rates can be obviously found, which are generally stable, showing the long-term stability of the electrode/electrolyte interface. Furthermore, the electrochemical performances of NMC/Li batteries at 0.3C are illustrated in Fig. 7(d), from which it can be seen that the NMC|10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li battery still remains at a capacity of 99.7 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles, which has a low capacity decay of just 29.8%. Whereas, the discharge capacity of NMC|0 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI|Li cell is only 53.2 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles, and the capacity decay rate reaches up to 58.0%. It can be observed that the Coulomb efficiency of the cell equipped with 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte is consistently retained at around 99.8%. And as manifested in Fig. 7(e), the charge–discharge curves of the battery equipped with 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte at 0.3C always has relatively smooth charging-discharging platforms, which indicates superior interface compatibility of the high-voltage cathode and 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte. As shown in Table 1 , when compared with the solid-state lithium batteries with other composite electrolytes, the assembled battery equipped with the 10 GDS NTs/PEO/LiTFSI composite electrolyte also has excellent electrochemical performance. 4 Conclusions In summary, the GDS NTs have been successfully synthesized and are used to prepare the PEO-based composite electrolytes. The oxygen-vacancy-rich GDS NTs with hollow structure can provide more organic/inorganic interfaces and long-range continuous lithium ion transport channels. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the addition of GDS NTs also can improve the mechanical strength and validly inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. Consequently, the 10 GDS NTs/PEO /LiTFSI composite electrolyte exhibit much higher lithium ion conductivity (2.41 × 10–4 S cm−1 at 30 ℃), lithium ion transference number (0.62) and better cycling stability than that of the monolithic polymer electrolyte. More importantly, the assembled Li/Li battery can maintain steady at three kinds of capacities (0.1, 0.2, and 0.3 mA h cm−2). In particular, at a capacity of 0.3 mA h cm−2, the assembled Li/Li symmetric battery can be cycled steadily for 1500 h. And the Li/LiFePO4 and Li/NMC batteries using composite electrolytes also exhibit superior cycling stability with high Coulombic efficiency, which will provide an advanced design strategy for ultra-long-life all-solid-state lithium metal batteries. coredata.dc:description: All-solid-state electrolytes are exceedingly attractive because of the outstanding inherent safety and energy density compared to liquid electrolytes. Whereas, it is still formidable to simultaneously design solid electrolytes with favorable electrode/electrolyte interface compatibility and high ionic conductivity in a simple and scalable manner. Hence, the oxygen-vacancy-rich Gd-doped SnO2 nanotubes (GDS NTs) are innovatively prepared and applied to the electrolyte of all-solid-state lithium metal batteries for the first time. The addition of GDS NTs can validly construct long-range continuous ion transport networks in the poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO)-based system and greatly improve the mechanical properties of the electrolyte. Compared to the PEO-based electrolyte, the composite electrolyte displays a higher lithium ion conductivity of 2.41 × 10–4 S cm−1 at 30 ℃, a higher lithium ion transference number up to 0.62 and a wider electrochemical window of 5 V at 50 ℃. In addition, the composite electrolyte manifests outstanding compatibility with high-voltage LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) cathode, LiFePO4 cathode and lithium metal anode. The assembled Li/Li symmetric battery exhibits stable Li plating/stripping cycling performance, which can cycle steadily for 1500 h at a capacity of 0.3 mA h cm−2. And Li/LiFePO4 battery still maintains a high capacity of 131.54 mA h g−1 at 0.5C after 800 cycles, which has a superior capacity retention rate of 93.2%. The obtained novel composite electrolyte has promising application prospects in the field of all-solid-state lithium metal cells.

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced ionic conductivity in a novel composite electrolyte based on Gd-doped SnO2 nanotubes for ultra-long-life all-solid-state lithium metal batteries
